div.p: From Ernst Betche to Joseph Maiden
Royal Botanic Garden and National Herbarium of New South Wales, Sydney.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p: MS found with a specimen of Brachyscome decipiens (coll. Bäuerlen 2156, Fagan's Creek, October 1898 (NSW 228424). Also attached to the specimen is a note: 'sent Brachycomes to F.v.M. 17/4/94'. Paddington, 8.April 1894

I had your Brachycomes all this time in my office, but happened to be so busy with other things that I could not find the time to compare them with our Herbarium. Yesterday I took them home and examined them this morning, but with very little result.

It seems to me the most perplexing genus of the whole Flora, and none of the Keys published is satisfactory; all the characters run into each other, neither the wings of the achemes nor the radicel- or stem-leaves are constant. I wish Baron v. Mueller would publish a monography of the genus, but, I believe, even he, with his great experience and enormous herbarium-material would find great difficulties in settling the boundaries of the species. The whole genus seems to be in an unsettled state, that is, in a state of very active variation. Only 5 of all the N. S. Wales Brachycomes are figured; could not Mr Baker use his skill in drawing to figure any of the Brachycomes from which you have quite complete material? That would be a first step to the difficult monography of the genus.

Much obliged for the copy of the descreption of Aster Bellis
I suspect that this is a bit of shorthand for something like the "Aster like plant
Bellis", but can't be sure enough to assert that, or even to suggest it. There is no name in Aster that even approximates this as far as I can see.
. The Hydrocotyle Mr Baker gave me, when I called last week, seems to me a peculiar form of H. Candollei .
